title: NFL Week 5: Green Bay Packers and Dallas Cowboys can stake NFC claim as leading MVP candidate emerges
text:
Get the biggest daily news stories by email Subscribe Thank you for subscribing We have more newsletters Show me See our privacy notice Could not subscribe, try again later Invalid Email

It’s all eyes on London for the Oakland Raiders vs Chicago Bears and this is a big one! There are a lot of storylines to this game.

Obviously we’ve got Khalil Mack taking on his old team. Jon Gruden and the Raiders did Hard Knocks this year, so they have a lot of personalities and notoriety from that.

They’ve had to really overcome a lot with the Antonio Brown issues, and this game in London is very important for them to get as a team.

They’ve been here the entire work, they’ve come together. It’s the simple things - eating dinner together, playing cards, hanging out when usually you’d just go to practice and go home.

This week they’ve had nothing but each other, and it’s underrated how important that is, especially for a team like the Raiders with all the issues they’ve had to deal with.

(Image: NFL)

As far as the match-up is concerned, everyone knows about this dominating Chicago defence. The Raiders need to give themselves a chance by starting fast.

The first 15-20 plays in their west coast offence will be scripted, and those will be what they consider their best plays and best match-ups.

They need to back up the Chicago defence with some vertical shots down the field, and scare them into backing off slightly.

Derek Carr has not been great throwing the ball down the field so far, but that’s not all on him and they need things to come together.

Packers and Cowboys look to emerge as NFC contenders

The Green Bay Packers vs the Dallas Cowboys is a huge match-up for a couple of reasons.

The big thing is, we still don’t know who the teams to beat at in the NFC. Both these teams are 3-1 and have a chance to become that team.

A win here catapults them into the conversation for being one of the best teams in the NFC.

Aaron Rodgers is going back to where he won his Super Bowl, so he has good memories of being in Dallas.

(Image: Getty Images)

This Cowboys defence is phenomenal, especially if they’re not on the field a lot. They just need their offence to have nice drives, control the ball with their run game and keep them off the field.

The Packers’ biggest issue is that Devante Adams is hurt. He’s been Aaron Rodgers’ go-to guy. Who is going to step up and be that consistent passing threat he needs?

I’m looking forward to seeing this Dallas defence be able to slow down Rodgers. It’s going to be tight, but that’s the match-up I’m looking for.

The Cowboys offence are going up against a defensive line which is much improved and likes to get after you in the pass game. They need to stick to running the ball and stopping them rushing the passer by using that play-action pass.

Russell Wilson playing like MVP

Russell Wilson is playing like the MVP of the league. That’s how good he’s playing right now.

He hasn’t thrown an interception this year and he’s just playing lights out.

(Image: SIPA USA/PA Images)

What’s so significant is that when he’s in prime time games, big games, when everyone is watching, he’s phenomenal. When the pressure is on him, he’s at his best.

That’s what you saw on Thursday, a guy that does things well when plays have to change and he has to adjust. He’s arguably the best in the league when things break down.

We saw a guy create plays and make throws all over the field with his pure athleticism and knowledge of the game.

He’s been outstanding so far this season. It’s fun to watch and I think we all hope he can keep up these standards.
description: Mirror NFL columnist JASON BELL looks at this week's London game between the Oakland Raiders and Chicago Bears as well as a huge NFC match-up
